Trial_Design.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised

Participants.evidence: Participants were adults undergoing elective thoracoabdominal surgery, eligible if they required postoperative analgesia.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received catheter-over-needle design, while the control group received catheter-through-needle design.

Objective.evidence: This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness and complications associated with different perineural catheter designs and fixation methods.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the duration of effective analgesia, measured over 48 hours postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was maintained for outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the intervention group and 100 to the control group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: 98 participants in the intervention group and 97 in the control group were analysed using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group showed a mean difference in analgesia duration of 5.2 hours (95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01) compared to the control.

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were reported in 3% of the intervention group and 1% of the control group, primarily mild infections.

Funding.evidence: Funding: This study was funded by the National Institute of Health.
